error.signature: Error: Rollback failed: no previous stable deployment found to revert to

verdict.summary: Automated deployment rollback fails because no previous stable version is recorded, the artifact registry was cleaned up, or the rollback process itself has a bug. Leaves the system in a partially deployed or broken state.

dead_ends.action: Manually SSH into production servers and revert files by hand
dead_ends.why_fails: Manual rollbacks are error-prone, skip health checks, bypass load balancers, and create drift between deployment state and CI records

dead_ends.action: Redeploy the current broken version hoping it works on second attempt
dead_ends.why_fails: If the deployment artifact is faulty, redeploying it will fail the same way; this wastes time during an incident

workarounds.action: Maintain immutable versioned artifacts and deployment history
workarounds.how: Tag every successful deployment with a version number, store artifacts with retention policies, and maintain a deployment log. Use 'kubectl rollout undo' for Kubernetes or keep previous task definitions in ECS

workarounds.action: Implement blue-green or canary deployment strategy with instant switchback
workarounds.how: Deploy new version alongside old version (blue-green) or route a small percentage of traffic to the new version (canary). On failure, switch traffic back to the known-good version instantly

leads_to.condition: When trying to find a previous deployment artifact that has been cleaned up

preceded_by.condition: When a failed Docker build leads to deploying a broken image, triggering rollback

frequently_confused_with.distinction: Rollback failure is about reverting a bad deployment; concurrency cancellation is about CI job scheduling conflicts
